There is something about this game that keeps you wanting to go back. It's really smartly designed. In a way, it's both simple and complex, it's vague and dark, but when you beat it, you realize it was so clear and bright.

The story is amazing, leaves a lot to think about, without being flooded with tons of cinematics and dialogue.

On cinematics, it has one of the best opening cinematic ever, so badass. I found an upscaled version of it on YT I watch it from time to time

The way New Game Plus loops into the story is something I experienced for the first time in this game, so smart, I felt that journey myself, understood it better, and wanted to go at it again

If you're new to the souls-like genre, this game can be frustrating if you're not patient. I know that the reputation is that these games are hard, and sure, they can be challenging, but think of them as they need problem-solving rather than get gud. There is always an easier way to tackle the obstacle at hand, you just need to find it.

The remastered version is a great upgrade, it runs smoothly with no issues and better anti-aliasing. I found it to be more visually appealing than DS2 Scholar of the First Sin.

Besides Blighttown being the true final boss of Dark Souls it is a masterpiece.

Back then in 2022, I played Elden Ring with hundreds of hours in it. That leads me to want more Dark Souls games. So here in 2025 I played Dark Souls Remastered. And I was amazed at how solid the gameplay, design, tricky dungeon, and Epic boss battle.

I thought Dark Souls 1 was just a really drawback version of Elden Ring, but all the game mechanics like deep weapon upgrade system, online PVP, the design on how the world connected to each other it’s still on par with Elden Ring.

Yes I know the world is smaller, the graphics are just mehh.. and the online system is not great like Elden Ring, however looking back on their first release which is 2011, it was amazing that From Software was able to pull this off. And they Remastered it in 2018.

[h2] Weapon & Armor Upgrade [/h2]
Grinding, you need to do repeating stuff here, like farming certain enemies to get the materials you need in order to level up your weapon and armor. And it has different types of materials needed on each certain level thus fighting different types of enemies are inevitable, so that makes grinding less repeating.

[h2] Graphics & Performance [/h2]
Although the graphics are not great, the performance and FPS is really good. I never had a lag or delay during any gameplay or any boss fight, that's a total improvement for me which had lots of issues with performance in Elden Ring lol.

I don’t mind the graphics as long as it has a stable FPS.

But for some reason I find it beautiful in some places during the [i] praise the sun message [/i] you will find this mostly on your journey.

[h2] Overall Gameplay [/h2]
The parry here is more forgiving compared to Elden Ring, the lighter the shield the more timing window you have for parrying attack. 

Different types of enemies, I just can’t count on how many different enemies in this game. And they have their own unique moveset. 

Tough boss fight especially for first timers, because you need to see what moveset that bosses have in order to find the attack timing window and healing.

Very interesting armor list and also a good amount of weapons to choose.

The only drawback here is when you are using mouse and keyboard it’s really challenging to perform jump attack and kick. This is just really something that needs to bind to other keys duh… (But You can’t, perhaps mod would do this trick) 

Becomes addicted as hell when you already know everything, and want to create another build for the next run or just go to NG+.

The attack and defense mechanics on each different level of dungeon is really amazing, it is still the best. This is where the Dark Souls genre was born.

Half of what happens in the 2nd half feels like artificial difficulty.

This game does an amazing job of making you feel like a badass the more you progress. The game throws what feels like impossible odds at first but slowly, over time, after every death, you learn, you adapt, you get more efficient at killing your target to the point where you don't even need an estus flask! What was once a boss level threat is now a common enemy as you make your way to the next boss. Oh and the world? Don't even get me started. In this dark fantasy RPG the world has moments of looking bleak, hopeless, and ugly but there some spots with exceptional beauty and inspire awe. The level design often regarded as the best. Dark Souls is for a very specific type of player. That player should be patient, calculating, determined, and detail-conscious. Only by paying close attention to every single detail, from item placement to enemy behavior, can you start to unwind what is unquestionably one of the greatest untold stories in gaming history. You must force the world to yield up its secrets, or be condemned to wallow in ignorance. There is a masterclass in storytelling occurring here that has taken a decade to unpack. 

All that said, the game actively tries to find ways to make you quit, and largely succeeds not due to the difficulty of enemy attack patterns or crazy timing, but rather an endless slog of bullshit that makes the simplest tasks an exercise in fortitude. In that regard the gameplay is more akin to arcade platformers, in spirit if not in execution. Prepare to run back through gauntlets to get to every boss battle, for boss battles that are as much about luck as skill, for an unforgiving combat system, and a constant battle between sunk-cost thinking and the question, "could I be playing something that doesn't make me scream and throw my controller?" Yes, yes you could. Still, even if it's not my cup of tea in comparison to its later entries, there is a lot of genuinely great material here that walked so Dark Souls 3 could run.

My second attempt to finish this game (the first attempt being the Prepare To Die Edition), and I just had to give up out of frustration again. The game isn't even necessarily HARD, it's just needlessly frustrating, and too many of the mechanics (and controls) seem to be clunky and janky purely for the sake of making the experience less streamlined. People with more patience than me may enjoy it.

Aside from the gameplay, one other thing that stands out as really bad is the grammar of some of the dialog, particularly when they're speaking Early Modern English. They constantly use the third-person singular simple present conjugation of verbs for the second-person. I've seen clips of later Souls games and this hasn't changed. An example:

"But cometh thee not for the grave of Sir Artorias?"

which should be "But comest thou not for the grave of Sir Artorias?"

The way it is written in the game it's the equivalent of saying "But it comes to you not..." as thee is used as an object and not the subject, and cometh is the wrong conjugation. Except for a few verbs, this is pretty much what happens across the board. Strangely enough, in certain places where they do use the second person singular simple present conjugation it is where the imperative should be used which is the same as the bare infinitive. Go figure. Another abomination is:

"Thou dost cometh."

As in Present-Day English, when using an auxiliary verb with a verb, the auxiliary verb is conjugated as normal and the verb it's modifying is the bare infinitive. You say "He comes" or "He does come" not "He does comes." And again, as always they're using the wrong conjugation of come so even if you drop the auxiliary verb it's still wrong. And all these examples are from just one of the many dialogues that use this language.

I know this is a strange thing to be critical of, and I know this is a Japanese studio, but maybe don't attempt to use archaic language for the dialogue. If you're not familiar with Early Modern English, you probably won't notice but if you are it's a bit immersion breaking as these characters are clearly not all making a conscious choice to use improper grammar.

Dark Souls is for a very specific type of player. That player should be patient, calculating, determined, and detail-conscious. Only by paying close attention to every single detail, from item placement to enemy behavior, can you start to unwind what is unquestionably one of the greatest untold stories in gaming history. You must force the world to yield up its secrets, or be condemned to wallow in ignorance. There is a masterclass in storytelling occurring here that has taken a decade to unpack. 

All that said, the game actively tries to find ways to make you quit, and largely succeeds not due to the difficulty of enemy attack patterns or crazy timing, but rather an endless slog of bullshit that makes the simplest tasks an exercise in fortitude. In that regard the gameplay is more akin to arcade platformers, in spirit if not in execution. Prepare to run back through gauntlets to get to every boss battle, for boss battles that are as much about luck as skill, for an unforgiving combat system, and a constant battle between sunk-cost thinking and the question, "could I be playing something that doesn't make me scream and throw my controller?" Yes, yes you could. Still, even if it's not my cup of tea in comparison to its later entries, there is a lot of genuinely great material here that walked so Dark Souls 3 could run.

Aside from the gameplay, one other thing that stands out as really bad is the grammar of some of the dialog, particularly when they're speaking Early Modern English. They constantly use the third-person singular simple present conjugation of verbs for the second-person. I've seen clips of later Souls games and this hasn't changed. An example:

"But cometh thee not for the grave of Sir Artorias?"

which should be "But comest thou not for the grave of Sir Artorias?"

The way it is written in the game it's the equivalent of saying "But it comes to you not..." as thee is used as an object and not the subject, and cometh is the wrong conjugation. Except for a few verbs, this is pretty much what happens across the board. Strangely enough, in certain places where they do use the second person singular simple present conjugation it is where the imperative should be used which is the same as the bare infinitive. Go figure. Another abomination is:

"Thou dost cometh."

As in Present-Day English, when using an auxiliary verb with a verb, the auxiliary verb is conjugated as normal and the verb it's modifying is the bare infinitive. You say "He comes" or "He does come" not "He does comes." And again, as always they're using the wrong conjugation of come so even if you drop the auxiliary verb it's still wrong. And all these examples are from just one of the many dialogues that use this language.

I know this is a strange thing to be critical of, and I know this is a Japanese studio, but maybe don't attempt to use archaic language for the dialogue. If you're not familiar with Early Modern English, you probably won't notice but if you are it's a bit immersion breaking as these characters are clearly not all making a conscious choice to use improper grammar.

You spend almost all of your time either in a boss battle or trying to get to the next one. I do have to say the opening sequence for this game is 100 times better than the one for Elden Ring.
